title: Using the right-left or spiral rule to decipher C declaration
The “right-left” rule is a completely regular rule for deciphering C declarations. It can also be useful in creating them.

inline_content.Text: The “right-left” rule is a completely regular rule for deciphering C declarations. It can also be useful in creating them.

title: Read the symbols as you encounter them in the declaration…

inline_content.Text: Read the symbols as you encounter them in the declaration…

title:
*   as "pointer to"          - always on the left side
[]  as "array of"            - always on the right side
()  as "function returning"  - always on the right side

content_resolved.code:
*   as "pointer to"          - always on the left side
[]  as "array of"            - always on the right side
()  as "function returning"  - always on the right side

title: Find the identifier. This is your starting point. Then say to yourself, “identifier is.” You’ve started your declaration.

inline_content.Text: Find the identifier. This is your starting point. Then say to yourself, “identifier is.” You’ve started your declaration.

title: Look at the symbols on the right of the identifier. If, say, you find
c
there, then you know that this is the declaration for a function. So you would then have
“identifier is function returning”
i
. Or if you found a
c
there, you would say
“identifier is array of”
i
. Continue right until you run out of symbols OR hit a right parenthesis
c
. (If you hit a left parenthesis
c
, that’s the beginning of a
c
symbol, even if there is stuff in between the parentheses. More on that below.)

title: Look at the symbols to the left of the identifier. If it is not one of our symbols above (say, something like “int”), just say it. Otherwise, translate it into English using that table above. Keep going left until you run out of symbols OR hit a left parenthesis
c

inline_content.Text: Look at the symbols to the left of the identifier. If it is not one of our symbols above (say, something like “int”), just say it. Otherwise, translate it into English using that table above. Keep going left until you run out of symbols OR hit a left parenthesis

title: Now repeat steps 2 and 3 until you’ve formed your declaration.

inline_content.Text: Now repeat steps 2 and 3 until you’ve formed your declaration.

title: Now, move right until out of symbols or right parenthesis hit.

inline_content.Text: Now, move right until out of symbols or right parenthesis hit.

title: Can’t move right anymore (out of symbols), so move left and find:

inline_content.Text: Can’t move right anymore (out of symbols), so move left and find:

title: “p is array of pointer to int”.
i

inline_content.Text: “p is array of pointer to int”.

title: (or
“p is an array where each element is of type pointer to int”
i

inline_content.Text: “p is an array where each element is of type pointer to int”

title: Can’t move right anymore because of the right parenthesis, so move left.

inline_content.Text: Can’t move right anymore because of the right parenthesis, so move left.

title: Can’t move left anymore because of the left parenthesis, so keep going right.

inline_content.Text: Can’t move left anymore because of the left parenthesis, so keep going right.

title: “func is function returning pointer to function returning”
i

inline_content.Text: “func is function returning pointer to function returning”

title: Can’t move right anymore because we’re out of symbols, so go left.

inline_content.Text: Can’t move right anymore because we’re out of symbols, so go left.

title: “func is function returning pointer to function returning pointer to”
i

inline_content.Text: “func is function returning pointer to function returning pointer to”

title: And finally, keep going left, because there’s nothing left on the right.

inline_content.Text: And finally, keep going left, because there’s nothing left on the right.

title: “func is function returning pointer to function returning pointer to int”.
i

inline_content.Text: “func is function returning pointer to function returning pointer to int”.

title: As you can see, this rule can be quite useful. You can also use it to sanity check yourself while you are creating declarations, and to give you a hint about where to put the next symbol and whether parentheses are required.

inline_content.Text: As you can see, this rule can be quite useful. You can also use it to sanity check yourself while you are creating declarations, and to give you a hint about where to put the next symbol and whether parentheses are required.

title: Some declarations look much more complicated than they are due to array sizes and argument lists in prototype form. If you see
c
, that’s read as
“array (size 3) of…”
i
. If you see
(char *,int)
c
that’s read as *“function expecting (char
,int) and returning…”
i

inline_content.Text: Some declarations look much more complicated than they are due to array sizes and argument lists in prototype form. If you see

title: I won’t go through each of the steps to decipher this one.

inline_content.Text: I won’t go through each of the steps to decipher this one.

title: *“fun_one is pointer to function expecting (char
,double) and returning pointer to array (size 9) of array (size 20) of int.”
i

inline_content.Text: ,double) and returning pointer to array (size 9) of array (size 20) of int.”

title: As you can see, it’s not as complicated if you get rid of the array sizes and argument lists:

inline_content.Text: As you can see, it’s not as complicated if you get rid of the array sizes and argument lists:

title: You can decipher it that way, and then put in the array sizes and argument lists later.

inline_content.Text: You can decipher it that way, and then put in the array sizes and argument lists later.

title: It is quite possible to make illegal declarations using this rule, so some knowledge of what’s legal in C is necessary. For instance, if the above had been:

inline_content.Text: It is quite possible to make illegal declarations using this rule, so some knowledge of what’s legal in C is necessary. For instance, if the above had been:

title: it would have read
“fun_one is pointer to function returning array of array of pointer to int”
i
. Since a function cannot return an array, but only a pointer to an array, that declaration is illegal.

inline_content.Text: “fun_one is pointer to function returning array of array of pointer to int”
. Since a function cannot return an array, but only a pointer to an array, that declaration is illegal.

title:
[]() - cannot have an array of functions
()() - cannot have a function that returns a function
()[] - cannot have a function that returns an array

content_resolved.code:
[]() - cannot have an array of functions
()() - cannot have a function that returns a function
()[] - cannot have a function that returns an array

title: In all the above cases, you would need a set of parentheses to bind a
c
symbol on the left between these
c
and
c
right-side symbols in order for the declaration to be legal.

inline_content.Text: In all the above cases, you would need a set of parentheses to bind a
symbol on the left between these
right-side symbols in order for the declaration to be legal.

title:
int i;               an int
int *p;              an int pointer (ptr to an int)
int a[];             an array of ints
int f();             a function returning an int
int **pp;            a pointer to an int pointer (ptr to a ptr to an int)
int (*pa)[];         a pointer to an array of ints
int (*pf)();         a pointer to a function returning an int
int *ap[];           an array of int pointers (array of ptrs to ints)
int aa[][];          an array of arrays of ints
int *fp();           a function returning an int pointer
int ***ppp;          a pointer to a pointer to an int pointer
int (**ppa)[];       a pointer to a pointer to an array of ints
int (**ppf)();       a pointer to a pointer to a function returning an int
int *(*pap)[];       a pointer to an array of int pointers
int (*paa)[][];      a pointer to an array of arrays of ints
int *(*pfp)();       a pointer to a function returning an int pointer
int **app[];         an array of pointers to int pointers
int (*apa[])[];      an array of pointers to arrays of ints
int (*apf[])();      an array of pointers to functions returning an int
int *aap[][];        an array of arrays of int pointers
int aaa[][][];       an array of arrays of arrays of int
int **fpp();         a function returning a pointer to an int pointer
int (*fpa())[];      a function returning a pointer to an array of ints
int (*fpf())();      a function returning a pointer to a function returning an int
